concepts.concept_name: States of matter and their properties
Change of state of matter and latent heat

in_scope: Matter is made up of particles
Particles of matter have space between them
Particles of matter are continuously moving (kinetic energy)
Particles of matter attract each other (intermolecular forces)
Rigid, fluid, compressibility, diffusion properties of states
Solid: definite shape and volume, strong intermolecular forces
Liquid: definite volume, no definite shape, moderate intermolecular forces
Gas: no definite shape or volume, weak intermolecular forces
Effect of temperature and pressure on states of matter
Melting point, boiling point definitions
Latent heat of fusion and latent heat of vaporisation
Sublimation, deposition, condensation, freezing
Evaporation as a surface phenomenon
Factors affecting evaporation: temperature, surface area, humidity, wind speed
Evaporation causes cooling
out_of_scope: Plasma and Bose-Einstein condensate states — Higher classes
Detailed thermodynamics and enthalpy calculations — Class 11

in_scope: Elements: metals, non-metals, metalloids — basic classification
Compounds: formed by chemical combination, fixed ratio
Difference between mixtures and compounds
Homogeneous mixtures (solutions): uniform composition throughout
Heterogeneous mixtures: non-uniform composition
Solution: solute, solvent, concentration, saturated and unsaturated
Suspension: heterogeneous, particles visible, settles on standing
Colloid: Tyndall effect, heterogeneous but appears homogeneous
Separation methods: evaporation, centrifugation, chromatography, distillation, simple and fractional distillation, sublimation, crystallisation
Physical vs chemical changes
out_of_scope: Mole concept and stoichiometry — Class 9 Chapter 3 (Atoms and Molecules)
Ionic and covalent bonding in detail — Class 10-11
Raoult's law and colligative properties — Class 12

concepts.concept_name: Atoms, molecules, ions and chemical formulae
Atomic mass, molecular mass and mole concept

in_scope: Law of conservation of mass (Lavoisier)
Law of constant proportions (Proust)
Dalton's atomic theory: postulates and limitations
Atom: smallest particle of an element
Symbols of elements (IUPAC conventions)
Atomic mass and atomic mass unit (amu/u)
Molecule: smallest particle of a substance retaining its properties
Atomicity: mono-, di-, tri-, polyatomic molecules
Ions: cations and anions
Valency and writing chemical formulae
Molecular mass calculation
Formula unit mass for ionic compounds
Mole concept: Avogadro's number (6.022 x 10^23)
Molar mass and relating moles to mass and number of particles
out_of_scope: Subatomic particles in detail — Class 9 Chapter 4 (Structure of Atom)
Advanced stoichiometry and limiting reagent — Class 11
Modern atomic theory and quantum mechanics — Class 11

concepts.concept_name: Atomic number, mass number, isotopes and isobars

in_scope: Electron: discovery by J.J. Thomson, charge and mass
Proton: discovery, charge and mass
Neutron: discovery by Chadwick, charge and mass
Thomson's model of atom: plum pudding model
Rutherford's alpha particle scattering experiment
Rutherford's nuclear model of atom
Limitations of Rutherford's model
Bohr's model of atom: energy levels/shells
Maximum electrons in shells: 2n^2 rule
Electron distribution (electronic configuration) for first 20 elements
Valence electrons and valency
Atomic number (Z) = number of protons
Mass number (A) = protons + neutrons
Isotopes: same atomic number, different mass numbers
Isobars: same mass number, different atomic numbers
